user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint:
```c
bool OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    const char *                  target = (const char *)ref;
    size_t                        mplen;

    filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, *token);

    if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_VIRTUAL) == 0)
    {
        return false;
    }

    mplen = OS_strnlen(filesys->virtual_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt));

    /*
     * The virtual_mountpt member should be a substring of the search target.
     * If this matches a basic substring check then it may be match
     */
    if (mplen == 0 || mplen >= sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt) ||
        strncmp(target, filesys->virtual_mountpt, mplen) != 0)
    {
        /* not a substring, so not a match */
        return false;
    }

    /*
     * Confirm that the substring ends at either a directory separator
     * or the end of string  (so exact mount points also match).
     *
     * For instance consider a virtual_mountpt of /mnt/abc and searching
     * for target=/mnt/abcd - this should return false in that case.
     */
    return (target[mplen] == '/' || target[mplen] == 0);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_filesys_internal_record_t OS_filesys_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct
{
    char device_name[OS_FS_DEV_NAME_LEN]; /**< The name of the underlying block device, if applicable */
    char volume_name[OS_FS_VOL_NAME_LEN];
    char system_mountpt[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN]; /**< The name/prefix where the contents are accessible in the host
                                                   operating system */
    char virtual_mountpt[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN]; /**< The name/prefix in the OSAL Virtual File system exposed to applications
                                            */
    char *            address;
    size_t            blocksize;
    osal_blockcount_t numblocks;
    uint8             flags;
    uint8             fstype;
} OS_filesys_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_VIRTUAL 0x20
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected the checks and the final indexed return as items to investigate because they contain conditions or indexing that can interact with string-termination/length invariants and could render branches effectively unreachable (or could lead to out-of-bounds accesses if assumptions are violated). Specifically, the computation of mplen via OS_strnlen and the combined condition that tests mplen == 0, mplen >= sizeof(...), and the strncmp result are the places where a logical invariant might make some of those subconditions always true or always false, which would imply unreachable code paths elsewhere. The final return indexing target[mplen] should be checked together with the earlier conditions to ensure it is always valid and not skipped/unreachable under all real inputs.

Other fragments in the function were not included because they are straightforward and do not on their own indicate unreachable code: variable declarations and the cast of ref to target are simple initializations and cannot be "unreachable code" by themselves; the call to OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET is a direct table lookup (the macro expands to an expression that computes an index and takes its address) and does not contain conditional branches that could be unreachable; comments and explanatory text do not affect control flow. These items therefore do not need investigation for Rule 2.1 in this routine.
